Articles.Content:
So I was testing some stuff, for my mun base, and

um... what are those green-blackish spots on the ground?! A change of plans!

So I crashed in to the ground to see what it was.

YES! Trees! and even near KSC!

Okay, now we are on a mission!(over-enthusiasm warning)

After landing, I didn't have enough torque to flip the rover on its wheels(even I was verticaly).

So sprinting with 4 times physics warp is also a good thing.

And now, the first kerbal besides a tree: I present to you, uh. I don't remember his name.

Look at all those other trees, and the width of the logs! Even the largest fuel tanks aren't that big!(KSP logic:huh:)

EDIT: I am sorry for posting this in the wrong section(general discussion). Now it is in the good place

Edited June 6, 2013 by joppiesaus
Yes!!! Finally .20.2 seems to have fixed the missing tree problem.

You don't know how happy this makes me, to see the trees again, I spotted them near the launchpad as well

I thought my game was totally bugged, as no one else seemed to have any issues (or didn't notice they were gone)
Whuh...whahh? I've never seen a single tree in game This is so unfair... And updating to 20.2 did not change this fact. My Kerbin is still tree-less.

Whuh...whahh? I've never seen a single tree in game This is so unfair... And updating to 20.2 did not change this fact. My Kerbin is still tree-less.

Have you ground scatter turned on? You need terrain scatter on to see them.

I noticed their absence, but I thought it was just that I was landing in treeless areas.

Then after installing 20.2, I starting seeing them when at the runway.

They have grow quite a bit in there absence it would seem.
Yeah, I am really glad I stand next to a tree

where is download link trees

how to add trees

19 minutes ago, jooly kerman said:

where is download link trees

how to add trees

You just need to change the graphic graphics settings. I think you need to turn "ground scatter" on or something like that.mit causes some minor lag, so be cautious when you select the frequency of the trees.
